text: - Welcome back to this AWS TechShift
migrate and modernize video mini series.

These videos are aimed at
independent software vendors
who are currently running on premise
and looking to migrate the cloud.

It's also aimed at those that
have existing applications
that they're looking to rearchitect
to become more cloud native.

In the last video, we made
the final improvements

to our photo gallery
case study application
by adding in an EC2 autoscaling group.
And we used cloud formation

to define the entire
infrastructure as code.
In this video,

we will summarize the
changes that we have made
and learn where to go next

to learn more about the
AWS TechShift program.
(upbeat music)

We started with the photo
gallery hosted on a single server

on premise with users
accessing it over the internet.

This was their migrated
AWS via a lift and shift
to Amazon EC2 running on a single instance
in single availability zone.

We then made several
incremental improvements

to the architecture to
increase the overall security,

reliability, performance
efficiency, and resilience.
And this ensures we're now following

some of the best practice
principles described
in the AWS Well-Architected Framework.

These included adding
more subnets to the VPC

to allow the use of
more availability zones,

separating out the
database to Amazon Aurora
as a managed database service,

storing images on Amazon
S3 for 11 nines durability,

low-cost storage, and offload
requests from the web server,

adding Amazon CloudFront
to cache the static content
close to where our end users are,
improving the overall performance,
and adding infrastructure as code.

We've completed our
initial TechShift journey
in this video mini series.
But this is just the beginning.
We've given you a flavor
of the Embark workshop path
and an overview of our migrate content.
Embark itself consists of
a one-to-many-events training workshops,
prescriptive guidance, and hands-on labs.
It's split into three phases,
Migrate, Modernize, and SaaS fundamentals.

On the Migrate phase, we
focus on the building blocks

required to install and run
your software applications
in the cloud.

In the Modernize phase,
we focus on optimization

and cloud native integration
through autoscaling,
no SQL, containers, and CI/CD pipelines.

And lastly, at the Software
as a Service stage,

we cover SaaS fundamentals,
such as tenant isolation,
onboarding, data partitioning.
And these are in different formats.

Migrate and Modernize are
available in a one-day format
or a two-day format for Modernize.

And we run the SaaS fundamentals
workshop in two hours.
Both Migrate and Modernize provide you

with hands-on labs to get
you a deeper experience

and understanding of
how these services work.

And in addition, you'll
have time to discuss
architecture patterns and best practices
with an AWS solution architect.

These can include also follow
up virtual office hours

to validate and answer your
technical queries directly.

But what happens if you're
already in the depths
of your modernization?
We also have the Expert path.
Expert path events focus on key topics
such as moving databases
and understanding which database types
may work for your data.
Or our Analytics and Machine Learning path

where you can realize the
benefits of the data you have

to generate deeper insights
using the portfolio
of AWS analytics and AI-ML services.

If you'd like to find
out more about how ISVs

are innovating on AWS,
check out the ISV page
at aws.amazon.com/campaigns/ISV.
If you click on the resources tab

and filter on event type
for virtual and webinar,

you'll see the upcoming
TechShift Embark workshops

and other technical and business
workshops relevant to ISVs.
Thank you for watching this video series.
We hope you enjoyed it.
We look forward to seeing you
at the next TechShift Embark workshop.
If you'd like to get in touch

to discuss the next steps
in your cloud journey,

please contact us at
techshift-emea@amazon.com.
(bright music)
